fol.206r
S
r
. Yo
r
last
latest
l
res
be of the xiijth & xvjth of this moneth,
those of the xiijth weare to recommend a request of the states for
the increase of hir
Ma
ties
Bandes of horsemen being foure Cornett
for
vj monethes. for w
ch
purpose the deputies here of the states have
presented a l
re
to hir Ma
tie
from the
Counsell of Estate
, wheare
I find hir Ma
tie
for manie respect
not to be hasty to awnswear:
The former letter of the xiijth conteined sondrie matters w
ch
I have
communicated unto hir Ma
tie
, whereof at this present I have noe leasure
to make perticuler recitall, for the occasion of my writing nowe at this
p
nt
is a matter that requireth great hast to be expedited, & w
th
great
discretion to be ordered by yowe, whereof I doe lesse dowbt to be
well used by yowe, by the experience I have of yo
r
Actions, than
the case will be delivered by mee in writinge, bicause I am forced to
use som hast. I
dowbt
not but
S
r
John Norris
hath communi-
cated unto yowe his Com
on
& Instruc
o
ns, whose principall charge
thither was to withdrawe if he cowld 3000 men of the Auxiliary
Cumpanies to be caried into
Britaigne
: and for that yt was
dowbted that the states would not consent theareunto, in one part
of his Instruc
o
ns he was directed that in such a Case of refusall
he should cawse the Capteines to
p
r
tend to
Casse her
soldiers
b
a
d
, as thowgh theye
showd not remaine in paie anie longer, and
yet to
direct the
m
soldiers
to cum to
Berghen
or to
flushinge,
wheare theie showld be reteined into paye
wthout losse, or if that meane should not be thowght convenient
betwixt him and the Capteines
whose advise he shuld use therin
then he should devise sum other good
meanes to bringe the same to passe according to his discretion, whereby
to com to be shipped into
England:
uppon this point
of his instructi
o
s
hir Ma
tie
hath entred into Considerac
o
n dowbting
[.]
howe the same shall
be executed w
th
owt som disagrement either betwixt the Capteines
and S
r
John Norris, or betwixt the soldiers & S
r
John Norris
fol.206v
and som Cawse hir Ma
tie
hath to conveie dowbt hearin bicause
hir Ma
tie
calleth to remembrance som unkindnes that hath heretofore
been betwene S
r
John Norris and sum of the principall Capteines
theare, and the same by sharpe word
, of reproches & Compa-
risons, and by sum offers of blowes was of late [time] heare in
England attempted, betwixt him and his brother, and sum of the
Capteines that nowe be theare of whome hir Ma
tie
hath vearye
good Reputac
o
n: And nowe therefore hir Ma
tie
hath some
dowbt howe this past abovementioned in his Instruct
o
ns will
be quietly executed; and sum further dowbt hir Ma
tie
hath
also that sum of the said Capteines for such former unkindnes
or for dowbt of sum hard usage of them by S
r
John Norris
if theie shall
s
rve under him, that sum of them will [repaire]
and refuse to cum w
th
their Band
in this
s
rvice and in that
case also their bandes will be unwillinge to cum, whereof hir
Ma
tie
thinketh theare will ensewe sum inconvenience, and that
w
ch
hir Ma
tie
would most of all mislike, an open knowledge
to the Enemie to see such a dissention betwixt her good
s
rviteurs and soldiers, and for remedie hereof hir Ma
tie
hath
had divers devises propounded, as in sum part to have S
r
John Norris revoked, and to have charge heare of newe nom-
bers that showld be levied in the Realme, for his [Journeie] of
Bretaigne, and the charge of such nombers as maie be gotten
thence, to be committed to
S
r
Francis Veere
, w
th
whome yt
hath been thowght heare, that sondrie of the principall
Capteines theare and their Bandes, would be more willingly
conducted, than by S
r
John Noriss, bicause of the former unkindnes
and discord
; But yet hir Ma
tie
not soe well likinge of this
fol.207r
advise, hath thowght it better to have the inconvenience
salved, by this meanes followinge. Hir Ma
tie
consideringe
that yowe are theare hir Counsello
r
and of Creditt by yo
r
owne
desart, and also takinge yowe to be indifferentlye affected toward
S
r
John Norris and the rest of the Capteines, and at the least
yowe will soe be in respect of hir Ma
ties
s
rvice, and
e honno
r
of her nation: hir pleasure is that yowe shall doe all the
good offices yowe can to procure that this
s
rvice committed to S
r
John Norris, might be performed w
th
quietnes and good Accord
betwixt him and the Capteines, and spetiallie w
th
owt anie
owtward showe of discord: and if yowe shall finde in either of the
sides anie wilfulnes to yeld to reasonable order for hir Ma
ties
s
rvice, yowe shall privatlie use hir Ma
ties
name (for so yt
is her pleasure) to charge them uppon paine of her Indignation
not for anie respect of former unkindnes or discord to refuse to doe
that w
ch
in reason on both part
owght to be done, aswell on the
part of S
r
John Norris, as forbearing from all hard usage of any
of the Capteines in worde or deade, or for exercising his authoritye
over anie of them to expresse his displeisure, And for the other
part for anie of the Capteiens wilfullie to refuse to come in this
s
rvice
or to disswade or discowrage their soldiers from the same, w
ch
if yo
w
shall finde notw
th
standinge yo
r
advise and Commaundment, so to
proceade, as by the refusall of the Capteines, and mislike of the soliders
this
s
rvice cannot take effect w
th
owt open dissenc
o
n: then yowe shall
after yowe have done the best yowe can w
th
the Capteines to winne them
to Conformitie, and that yowe shall see that the former unkindnes &
dissention hath been such, as the Capteines will not in anie wise be
perswaded to cum under S
r
John Norris Governm
t
, as fearing their
danger to be under his Commaundem
t
, yowe shall open yo
r
Conceipt to S
r
John Norris, and advise him hearein to forbeare from all extreme
fol.207v
1590/1 Fe
b
Un
i
Pr
o
Corses to the offence of the Capteines, and require him in hir
Ma
ties
name to force noe more of thes Capteines by the authoritye w
ch
he hath to cum from thence, but onelie to bringe such as he and yowe
by
yo
r
good
perswasions shall induce them to this
s
rvice, leaving the rest
that will not be perswaded to abide theare, untill
wee
hir Ma
ty
shall be informed
by yowe of their behavio
r
in refusing, and of the Cawses theareof so
as hir Ma
tie
maie determine hereafter, of their continuance or remo-
ving. I doe knowe yowe can use manie good reasons
and have the helpe of sum other of hir Ma
ties
s
rviteurs theare to
aide yowe in this yo
r
Negotiac
o
n for good Concord betwixt S
r
John Nor-
ris and the Capteines: And thowgh sum of the Capteines will alledge
that S
r
John Norris and his Brethren also have sought greatlye to
disgrace them, and that their dowbt of the continance of him in sto-
mack underhand to execute his displesure, wheare he shall have Rule
and governm
t
, yet yowe maie saie to them that hearein hir Ma
ty
will have such regard to overrule him, as he shall not dare to attempte
anie point of displeasure to anie of them in the time of their
s
rvice,
but will rather thinke yt to be in hir power to Commaund him to use
them as thowgh theare never had been anie such displesure:
or otherwise she will apoynt s
o
e other
s
o
of gretar call
y
g, to be head of the b
a
d
and soe
their have been manie examples, wheare great Noble men and
Capteines that have been privatlye at great discord in their Cuntries
and yet when their have been commaunded by their Superio
rs
to c
u
to place of
s
rvice, theie have honorablie vowed to suspend all privat
displesures, and to joine together in
s
rvice of their prince withowt
murmure or grudge, or anie slacknes to the best of their power:
and I thinke if otherwise thes parties will not forsake all unkindnes
and becom frendes as theie owght to doe, yet this motion to followe
thes examples of greate men than anie of thes be, owght to move them
to assent to the same: w
ch
if it shall not prevaile w
th
them, then
yowe shall direct S
r
John Noris to bringe over w
th
him as manye
as w
th
good will & perswasions will be induced theareto.
hir Ma
ty
wold also have it well Conisdered
t
if
e better sort of
e Capta
y
s w
t
the best band
of soldiors, shuld stay, wherby S
r
John Norreys
shuld be forced to br
y
g other band
, in
t
Case yow shuld advise
hym, not to br
y
g any weak or unhable soldiors, but
rather to leave th
e
, and to ch
a
g th
e
w
t
better to
be tak
e
out of bergh
e
, or els to br
y
g fewar. for he
knoweth how necessary it is to have [...] soldiors
for this
s
vice. hir Ma
ty
hav
y
g allowed of this my wryt
y
g
in hir name,
[...]
and hav
y
g my L. Admyrall p
r
sent w
t
hir at
e same
tyme, willed h
y
to joyn his hand to myne w
c
his L. doth and [...]
[...] s
o
e spedy answer hereunto,
I com
e
d yow to almighty God
